lesson.name: Lesson 1.13: Writing Equations of Parallel and Perpendicular Lines

page.title: 1.13.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will continue to examine methods of writing an equation of a line. In recent lessons, you learned that the method you use to write the equation of a line is determined by the information given. You will continue to use those methods along with the relationship between slopes of lines.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to: 

  • Write an equation of a line parallel to a given line.
  • Write an equation of a line perpendicular to a given line.
  • Write an equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to an axis.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 1.13.1: Using Point-Slope Form to Write the Equation of a Line
  • 1.13.2: Writing an Equation of a Line Parallel to a Given Line
  • 1.13.2: Self Check 
  • 1.13.3: Writing an Equation of a Line Perpendicular to a Given Line
  • 1.13.3: Self Check 
  • 1.13.4: Writing an Equation of a Line Parallel or Perpendicular to an Axis
  • 1.13.4: Self Check 
  • 1.13.5: Drawing Parallel and Perpendicular Lines

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 1.13.6: Practice
  • 1.13.7: Lesson Summary

page.title: 1.13.1: Using Point-Slope Form to Write the Equation of a Line
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Your teacher will assign you one pair of the points shown.

Points for Line A: \( (-1, 5) \) and \( (1, 1) \)
Points for Line B: \( (-1, -1) \) and \( (1, -5) \)

Use your assigned points to find the following:

1. Find the slope of the line.

Check your answer:

Line A: slope: \( m= \frac{1-5}{1-(-1)}=-2 \)
Line B: slope: \( m= \frac{-5-(-1)}{1-(-1)}=-2 \)

Remember to use the slope formula to find the slope: \( m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \).


2. Write the equation of the line in slope-intercept form.

Check your answer:

Line A: equation \( y = -2x + 3 \)
Line B: equation \( y = -2x - 3 \)

Remember to use the point-slope form for the equation of the line to write the equation: \( y - y_1 = m_1(x - x_1) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form \( y = mx + b \), where the slope is \( m \) and the \( y \)-intercept is \( b \).


3. Compare your equation to your partner’s equation.

Compare your answer to the sample responses:

Sample responses:

  • Both lines have a negative slope.
  • Both lines have the same slope.
  • The \( y \)-intercepts are different.
  • The \( y \)-intercepts have opposite signs.

page.title: 1.13.2: Writing an Equation of a Line Parallel to a Given Line
page.contents:
Activity

1. For each of the following slopes and points, find the equation of the line using point-slope form.

a. \( m = 2, (3, 1) \)
b. \( m = 2, (-1, 4) \)
c. \( m = -4, (2, 1) \)
d. \( m = -4, (3, -2) \)

Enter your answer here:

Check your answers: 

a. \( y - 1 = 2(x - 3) \)
b. \( y - 4 = 2(x +1) \)
c. \( y - 1 = -4(x -2) \)
d. \( y +2 = -4(x-3) \)


2. Write each of the four equations from the previous question in slope-intercept form.
Enter your answers here:

Check your answers: 

a. \( y = 2x -5 \)
b. \( y = 2x + 6 \)
c. \( y = -4x +9 \)
d. \( y = -4x +10 \)


3. Now, graph the equations \( a \) and \( b \) on one graph and \( c \) and \( d \) on another graph.

Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.

Sample answer:
Lines \( a \) and \( b \)

Lines \( c \) and \( d \)




4. What is the same in the equations?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer: 

The slopes are the same. They are both \( -4 \).


5.  What do you notice about the graphs?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The lines have the same slope and will never touch.


6. Here are some examples and non-examples of slopes of lines that are parallel.

Slopes of Parallel Lines
Examples Non-Examples
\( 5, 5 \) \( 5, -5 \)
\( -\frac{1}{7}, -\frac{1}{7} \) \( -7, -\frac{1}{7} \)
\( \frac{4}{9}, \frac{4}{9}\ \) \( \frac{4}{9}, -\frac{4}{9} \)


What do you notice about the pairs of examples of slopes of parallel lines?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Parallel lines have the same slope.


Parallel lines are lines that have the same slope. Because they have the same slope, they will never touch, or intersect.

7. Now, write an equation of a line that is parallel to \( y = \frac{1}{3}x -2 \) that goes through \( (9, 2) \).

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

\( y=\frac{1}{3}x-1 \) is an equation that is parallel to \( y = \frac{1}{3}x -2 \) and goes through \( (9, 2) \).

First, identify the slope of the line: 

\( m =\frac{1}{3} \)

Next, use the slope and given point \( (9, 2) \) in point-slope form to find the parallel line that goes through the point:

\( y-2=\frac{1}{3}(x-9) \)

Now put the equation in slope-intercept form (solve for \( y \)).

\( y=\frac{1}{3}x-1 \)

page.title: 1.13.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which equation represents an equation of a line parallel to the line \( y = \frac{1}{2} x - 3 \) that contains the point \( (6, 4) \)?

answer.response:
That’s correct! Check yourself: 

The slope of the parallel line is the same as the original line, \( \frac{1}{2} \). 

Substitute \( \frac{1}{2} \) for \( m \), \( 6 \) for \( x_1 \), and \( 4 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = \frac{1}{2}(x - 6) \) to get \( y - 4 =  \frac{1}{2}x - 3 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 

The slope of the parallel line is the same as the original line, \( \frac{1}{2} \). The point on the line is \( (6, 4) \). The first coordinate, \( 6 \), is the \( x \)-coordinate. The second coordinate, \( 4 \), is the \( y \)-coordinate. 

Substitute \( \frac{1}{2} \) for \( m \), \( 6 \) for \( x_1 \), and \( 4 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = \frac{1}{2}(x - 6) \) to get \( y - 4 =  \frac{1}{2}x - 3 \). The answer is \( y = \frac{1}{2}x + 1 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:

The slope of the parallel line is the same as the original line, \( \frac{1}{2} \).

Substitute \( \frac{1}{2} \) for \( m \), \( 6 \) for \( x_1 \), and \( 4 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = \frac{1}{2}(x - 6) \) to get \( y - 4 = \frac{1}{2}x - 3 \). Be sure to add \( 4 \) to both sides of the equation to solve for \( y \). The answer is \( y = \frac{1}{2}x + 1 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:

The slope of the parallel line is the same as the original line, \( \frac{1}{2} \).

Substitute \( \frac{1}{2} \) for \( m \), \( 6 \) for \( x_1 \), and \( 4 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = \frac{1}{2}(x - 6) \). Be sure to distribute \( \frac{1}{2} \) to both terms inside the parentheses to get \( y - 4 =  \frac{1}{2}x - 3 \). 

The answer is \( y = \frac{1}{2}x + 1 \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.13.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Find the Line Parallel to a Given Line

In this section, you will use what you know about writing the equation of a line given the slope and a point to write the equation of parallel lines. The graph shows the equation of the line \( y = 2x - 3. \) The point \( P \) \( (-2, 1) \) is also plotted. You can use the fact that parallel lines have the same slope to find a line that is parallel to line \(m\) and goes through point \( P \) \( (-2, 1) \). 



From the equation, you know the slope of the line is 2. The second line will pass through \( (-2, 1) \) and have slope 2. To graph the line, start at \( (-2, 1) \) and count out the rise and run. The slope is \( \frac{rise}{run}=\frac{2}{1} \). Count out the rise, 2, and run, 1, and plot the point. You can graph the line as shown. Line \( m \) is parallel to line \( l \) and goes through point \( P \) \( (-2, 1) \).


To find the equation of a line parallel to a line through a given point algebraically, you can use what you know about finding the equation of a line given the slope and a point.

For example,

Write an equation of a line parallel to \( y = 2x - 3 \) that contains the point \( (-2, 1) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.


Look at the graph with the parallel lines shown previously. Does this equation make sense? What is the \(y\)-intercept of the line? What is the slope?

You can use this table as a reference for writing an equation of a line parallel to a given line. 

Write the equation in slope-intercept form: \( y = mx+b \).

Step 1 Find the slope of the given line.
Step 2 Find the slope of the parallel line.
Step 3 Identify the point.
Step 4 Substitute the values into the point-slope form: 
\( y_2-y_1=m(x_2-x_1) \).
Step 5 Simplify.
Step 6 Write the equation in slope-intercept form: \( y = mx+b \).


Try It: Find the Line Parallel to a Given Line

Write an equation of a line parallel to the line \(y = 3x + 1\) that contains the point \( (4,2) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to find a line parallel to a given line and point.

Step 1 Find the slope of the given line.  \( m = 3 \)
Step 2 Find the slope of the parallel line.  \( m_1 = 3 \)
Step 3 Identify the point.  \( (x_1, y_1) \)
 \( (4, 4) \)
Step 4 Substitute the values into the point-slope form: 
\( y_2-y_1=m(x_2-x_1) \).		 \( y_2-y_1=m(x_2-x_1) \)
\( y-2=3(x-4) \)
Step 5 Simplify.  \( y - 2 = 3x - 12 \)
Step 6 Write the equation in slope-intercept form: \( y = mx+b \).  \( y = 3x - 10 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.13.3: Writing an Equation of a Line Perpendicular to a Given Line
page.contents:
Activity

1. For each of the following slopes and points, find the equation of the line using point-slope form.

a. \( m = 2, (3, 1) \)
b. \( m = -\frac{1}{2}, (-1, 4) \)
c. \( m = -4, (2, 1) \)
d. \( m = \frac{1}{4}, (3, 2) \)

Enter your answers here:

Check your answer:

a.  \( y - 1 = 2(x - 3) \)
b. \( y - 4\ =-\frac{1}{2}(x+1) \)
c. \( y - 1 = -4(x -2) \)
d. \( y-2\ =\frac{1}{4}(x-3) \)


2. Write each of the four equations from the previous question in slope-intercept form.
Enter your answers here:

Check your answers: 

a. \( y = 2x -5 \)
b. \( y=-\frac{1}{2}x+\frac{7}{2} \)
c. \( y= -4x +9 \)
d. \( y =\frac{1}{4}x+\frac{5}{4} \)


3. Graph the equations for a and b on one graph and the equations for c and d on another graph.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your graphs to these solution graphs:
Lines \( a \) and \( b \)


Lines \( c \) and \( d \)


4. What do you notice about the pairs of lines and their graphs?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The lines that have slopes that are opposite signs and reciprocals of each other are perpendicular to each other.


Perpendicular lines have slopes that have opposite signs and are reciprocals of each other. Here are some examples and non-examples of the slopes of lines that are perpendicular:

Slopes of Perpendicular Lines
Examples Non-Examples
\( 5, -\frac{1}{5}\) \( 5, -5 \)
\( -\frac{1}{7}, 7 \) \( -7, -\frac{1}{7} \)
\( \frac{4}{9}, -\frac{9}{4} \) \( \frac{4}{9}, -\frac{4}{9} \)

5. Complete the table to identify the slope of the line perpendicular to the line whose slope is given.

Slope of Line A Slope of Line B
\( \frac{1}{4} \) A
\( -8 \) B
\( -\frac{6}{11} \) C

Solutions:
A. \( -4 \)
B. \( \frac{1}{8} \)
C. \( \frac{11}{6} \)



6. Now, write the equation of a line perpendicular to \( y = 3x -1 \) that goes through \( (1,2) \).

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

\( y= -\frac{1}{3}x+\frac{7}{3} \) is an equation of a line that is perpendicular to \( y = 3x -1 \) and goes through \( (1,2) \).

First, find the slope of the given line: \( m = 3 \).

Next, find the opposite reciprocal of this slope: \( m = - \frac{1}{3} \).

This will be the slope of the perpendicular line. 

Now use this slope, \( m = - \frac{1}{3} \) and the given point, \( (1,2) \) to write an equation of a line with point-slope form: \( y - 2 = -\frac{1}{3}(x - 1) \).

Simplify and write in slope-intercept form: \( y= -\frac{1}{3}x+\frac{7}{3}+2 \)

\( y= -\frac{1}{3}x+\frac{7}{3} \)

page.title: 1.13.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which equation represents an equation of a line perpendicular to the line \( y = \frac{1}{2} x - 3 \) that contains the point \( (6, 4) \)?

answer.response:
That’s correct! Check yourself: 

The slope of the perpendicular line is the opposite reciprocal of the slope of the original line, \( -2 \). 

Substitute \( -2 \) for \( m \), 6 for \( x_1 \), and 4 for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = –2 (x - 6) \) to get \( y - 4 = -2x + 12 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 

The slope of the perpendicular line is the opposite reciprocal of the slope of the original line, \( -2 \). The point on the line is \( (6, 4) \). The first coordinate, 6, is the \( x \)-coordinate. The second coordinate, 4, is the \( y \)-coordinate. 

Substitute \( -2 \) for \( m \), 6 for \( x_1 \), and 4 for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = -2 (x - 6) \) to get \( y - 4 = -2x + 12 \). The answer is \( y = -2x + 16 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 

The slope of the perpendicular line is the opposite reciprocal of the slope of the original line. Remember to change the sign. The original line has slope \( \frac{1}{2} \). The opposite reciprocal is \( -2 \). 

Substitute \( -2 \) for \( m \), 6 for \( x_1 \), and 4 for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = -2 (x - 6) \) to get \( y - 4 = -2x + 12 \). The answer is \( y = -2x + 16 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:

The slope of the perpendicular line is the opposite reciprocal of the slope of the original line, \( -2 \). 

Substitute \( -2 \) for \( m \), 6 for \( x_1 \), and 4 for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = -2 (x - 6) \). Be sure to distribute \(-2\) to both terms inside the parentheses to get \( y - 4 = -2x + 12 \). 

The answer is \( y = -2x + 16 \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.13.5: Drawing Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

On the same coordinate grid:

  • Partner A draws a vertical line, and Partner B draws a horizontal line. 
  • Label each line with its equation in slope-intercept form.

Pass your paper to your partner. 

1. Check your partner’s graph and equation. 
Enter the equation here:

Partner A’s equation is of the form \( x =\) #, and Partner B’s equation is of the form \( y =\) #. 


2. Draw a point on your partner’s paper that is not on the line. Label the point \( P \).

3. Draw a line parallel to the original line that goes through point \( P \). Label the line with its equation.

The equation of your line will depend on where you drew it on the coordinate grid, but it should have the same slope (0 or undefined) as the first equation.


4. Draw a line perpendicular to the original line that goes through point \( P \). Label the line with its equation.
Enter the equation here:

The equation of your line will depend on where you drew it on the coordinate grid, but it should have a slope that is not the same as the first equation.


Share your graphs and equations with your partner. Decide if they are correct.

page.title: 1.13.4: Writing an Equation of a Line Parallel or Perpendicular to an Axis
page.contents:
Activity

The line \( x = 5 \) and the point \( (3, -2) \) are shown on the graph.


Work with a partner to complete the tasks:

1. Identify the slope of the original line, \( l \).

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

Undefined


2. Draw a line \( m \) parallel to the given line, \( l \), that goes through the point \( (3, -2) \). 

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your graph to this solution graph:



Then,

a. Identify the slope of the new line, \( m \). 
b. Write the equation of the new line, \( m \).

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:
a. Slope: Undefined
b. Equation: \( x = 3 \)


3. Draw a line \( n \) perpendicular to the given line, \( l \), through the point \( (3, -2) \). 

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your graph to this solution graph:



Then,

a. Identify the slope of the new line, \( n \). 
b. Write the equation of the new line, \( n \).

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:
a. Slope: 0
b. Equation: \( y = -2 \)

page.title: 1.13.4: Self Check
page.contents: Which is the equation that is perpendicular to the line \( x = 1 \) that contains the point \( (-5, 2) \).

answer.response:
That’s correct! Check yourself: 

The given line is vertical and has undefined slope. 

The perpendicular line is horizontal and has slope 0. Every point on the perpendicular line has a \( y \)-coordinate of 2.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 

The line you chose is parallel, not perpendicular. The given line is vertical and has undefined slope. 

The perpendicular line is horizontal and has slope 0. Every point on the perpendicular line has a \( y \)-coordinate of 2. 

The answer is \( y = 2 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 

The line you chose does not go through the point \( (-5, 2) \). The given line is vertical and has undefined slope. 

The perpendicular line is horizontal and has slope 0. Every point on the perpendicular line has a \( y \)-coordinate of 2. 

The answer is \( y = 2 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 

The line you chose does not go through the point \( (-5, 2) \). The given line is vertical and has undefined slope. 

The perpendicular line is horizontal and has slope 0. Every point on the perpendicular line has a \( y \)-coordinate of 2. 

The answer is \( y = 2 \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.13.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Finding a Perpendicular Line Given an Equation and Point

In this section, you will use what you know about writing the equation of a line given the slope and a point to write the equation of perpendicular lines. The graph shows the equation of the line \( y = 2x - 3 \). The point \( P(-2, 1) \) is also plotted. You can use the fact that perpendicular lines have slopes that are opposite reciprocals to find a line that is perpendicular to line \(l\) and goes through point \( P(-2, 1) \).


From the equation, you know the slope of the line is 2. The second line will pass through \( P(-2, 1) \) and have slope \( - \frac{1}{2} \). To graph the line, start at \( (-2, 1) \) and count out the rise and run. The slope is \( \frac{rise}{run}=\frac{-1}{2} \). Count out the rise, \( -1 \), and run, 2, and plot the point. You can graph the line as shown. Line \( n \) is perpendicular to line \( l \) and goes through point \( (-2, 1) \).


To find the equation of a line perpendicular to a line through a given point algebraically, you can use what you know about finding the equation of a line given the slope and a point.

For example,

Write an equation of a line perpendicular to \( y = 2x - 3 \) that contains the point \( (-2, 1) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.


Use this table for reference to write an equation of a line perpendicular to a given line:

Step 1 Find the slope of the given line.
Step 2 Find the slope of the perpendicular line.
Step 3 Identify the point.
Step 4 Substitute the values into the point-slope form: 
\( y_2-y_1=m(x_2-x_1) \).
Step 5 Simplify.
Step 6 Write the equation in slope-intercept form \( (y = mx+b) \).


Try It: Finding a Perpendicular Line Given an Equation and Point

Find an equation of a line perpendicular to the line \( y = 3x + 1 \) that contains the point \( (4, 2) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to find a line perpendicular to a given line and point.

Step 1 Find the slope of the given line.  \( m = 3 \)
Step 2 Find the slope of the perpendicular line.   \( m_1 = - \frac{1}{3} \)
Step 3 Identify the point.  \( (x_1, y_1) \)
 \( (4, 2) \)
Step 4_ Substitute the values into the point-slope form: 
\( y_2-y_1=m(x_2-x_1) \).		 \( y - y_1 = m_1(x - x_1) \)
\( 2 = -\frac{1}{3} (x - 4) \)
Step 5 Simplify.  \( y - 2 = -\frac{1}{3}x + \frac{4}{3} \)
Step 6 Write the equation in slope-intercept form \( (y = mx+b) \).  \( y = -\frac{1}{3}x + 3\frac{1}{3}  \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.13.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Find Equations of Lines Perpendicular to an Axis


Example 1:

Find an equation of a line perpendicular to \( x=5 \) that contains the point \( (3,-2) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

Again, since we know one point, the point-slope option seems more promising than the slope-intercept option. We need the slope to use this form, and we know the new line will be perpendicular to \( x=5 \). This line is vertical, so its perpendicular will be horizontal. This tells us the \( m_1=0 \).

Identify the point. \( (3,-2) \)
Identify the slope of the perpendicular line. \( m_1=0 \) 
Substitute the values into \( y-y_1=m(x-x_1) \). \( y-y_1=m(x-x_1) \)

\( y-(-2)=0(x-3) \)
Simplify. \( y+2=0 \)

\( y=-2 \)

Example 2:

Find an equation of a line that is perpendicular to \( y=4 \) that contains the point \( (2,3) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

The line \( y=4 \) is a horizontal line. Any line perpendicular to it must be vertical, in the form \( x=a \). Since the perpendicular line is vertical and passes through \( (2,3) \), every point on it has an \(x\)-coordinate of 2. The equation of the perpendicular line is \( x=2 \).

Try It: Find Equations of Lines Perpendicular to an Axis

Find an equation of a line that is perpendicular to \( y = -3 \) that contains the point \( (-3, 5) \).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to find the equation of a line perpendicular to \( y = -3 \) that contains the point \( (-3, 5) \).

Find the slope of the given line.  The line is horizontal. \( m = 0 \)
Find the slope of the perpendicular line. The perpendicular line is a vertical line. undefined
Identify the point. The given point is \((-3, 5)\).   \( (x_1, y_1) \)
\( (-3, 5) \)
Write the equation. The perpendicular line is vertical and passes through \( (-3, 5) \); every point on it has an \(x\)-coordinate of \( -3 \).  \( x = -3 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.13.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Write an equation of a line parallel to a given line.
  • Write an equation of a line perpendicular to a given line.
  • Write an equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to an axis.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 1.13.1: Using Point-Slope Form to Write the Equation of a Line 
    • In this activity, you used the slope formula to find the slope of a line. Using the slope and a point, you wrote equations in point-slope form and slope-intercept form.
  • 1.13.2: Writing an Equation of a Line Parallel to a Given Line
    • In this activity, you explored parallel lines that have the same slope. You also wrote the equation of lines parallel to given lines that went through a specific point.
  • 1.13.2: Self Check 
  • 1.13.3: Writing an Equation of a Line Perpendicular to a Given Line
    • In this activity, you explored perpendicular lines that have slopes that are opposite reciprocals of each other. You wrote the equations of lines that were perpendicular to a given line and went through a specific point.
  • 1.13.3: Self Check 
  • 1.13.4: Writing an Equation of a Line Parallel or Perpendicular to an Axis
    • In this activity, you wrote equations of lines parallel or perpendicular to an axis through a given point, given a line in the form \(x = a\) or \(y =b\).
  • 1.13.4: Self Check 
  • 1.13.5: Drawing Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
    • In this activity, you worked with a partner to draw parallel and perpendicular lines on a coordinate plane.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 1.13.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.

page.title: 1.13.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

In questions 1-5, choose an equation of a line parallel to the given line and contains the given point. The choices are in slope-intercept form.

1. Line y = 4x + 2
Point (1, 2)

Correct! \(y=4x-2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.13.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(y = 4x-2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


2. Line y = -3x -1
Point (2, -3)

Correct! \(y=-3x +3\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.13.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is y = -3x +3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


3. Line 2x - y = 6
Point (3, 0)

Correct! \(y=2x-6\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.13.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(y=2x-6\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


4. Line x = -4
Point (-3, -5)

Correct! \(x=-3\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.13.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x=-3\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


5. Line y = 5
Point (2, -2)

Correct! \(y=-2\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.13.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(y=-2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


6. Line y = -2x +3
Point (2, 2)

Correct! \(y=\frac12x+1\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.13.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(y=\frac12x+1\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


7. Line y = -x +5
Point (3, 3)

Correct! \(y=x\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.13.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(y=x\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


8. Line \(y=\frac34x-2\)
Point (-3, 4)

Correct! \(y=-\frac43x\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.13.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(y=-\frac43x\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


9. Line x = -5
Point (1, -2)

Correct! \(y=-2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.13.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(y=-2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


10. Line y - 3 = 0
Point (-2, -4)

Correct! \(x=-2\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.13.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x=-2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
